abstracts.cdata!:
Early on the government of Rwanda
            demonstrated strong commitment to both human
            immunodeficiency virus (HIV) prevention and treatment.
            Rwanda requested Bank assistance as part of the
            multi-country action program (MAP) against HIV and acquired
            immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) in Africa. The project is
            financed by a United States (U.S.) 30.5 million dollars
            International Development Association (IDA) grant and
            supports the full range of preventive, medical, and support
            services for those living with HIV and AIDS. Access to AIDS
            care and treatment has expanded to rural areas where the
            majority of Rwandans live on less than U.S. $.70 per day and
            HIV infections rates among youth in Rwanda has declined. The
            main challenge at this stage is to use the recently approved
            U.S. 10 million dollars grant to consolidate and sustain the
            gains from the initial investments and to develop a
            long-term financing strategy for HIV and AIDS.
